posts.title: ‚ÄúDid you know...‚Äù about ethnobotany.
posts.description: Ethnobotany studies how cultures have used plants for medicine, food and rituals. Many current remedies come from ancestral knowledge - every plant has a story to discover! üå±üí°

gallery.title: Get to know the corporation (our locations)

pill.title: CONTENTS
pill.content:
1. Introduction to ethnobotany and its importance in human cultures.
2. The relationship between plants and ancestral civilizations throughout time.
3. The traditional knowledge of indigenous peoples about plants and their use.
4. Medicinal plants: myths, realities and scientific validations.
5. Ethnobotany as a tool for biodiversity conservation.
6. Sacred plants and their role in the rituals of diverse cultures. 
7. The role of shamans and healers in transmitting ethnobotanical knowledge.

pill.title: INTRODUCTION
pill.content: “Did you know that Colombia, one of the most biodiverse countries in the world is home to thousands of plant species with traditional uses documented by indigenous communities?”. Ethnobotany is a fascinating science that studies how people, since ancient times, have used plants in their daily lives: as medicine, food, tools, spiritual symbols and much more. This knowledge has been transmitted orally throughout generations, forming a fundamental part of the cultural identity of indigenous, Afro-descendant and peasant communities in Colombia and Latin America. In this pill, you will discover curiosities, surprising stories and concrete examples of the traditional use of plants in our country, highlighting the connection between nature and culture.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
La etnobotánica es una disciplina científica que combina la botánica con la antropología, enfocándose en cómo las comunidades humanas usan las plantas. Esta ciencia fue impulsada por investigadores como Richard Evans Schultes, considerado el “Padre de la etnobotánica”, quien realizó extensos estudios en la Amazonía colombiana en el siglo XX, documentando el uso de plantas alucinógenas y medicinales por parte de tribus como los Tukano y los Witoto. 
En Colombia, gracias a su ubicación geográfica y diversidad cultural, existe más de 80 grupos étnicos que manejan un vasto conocimiento botánico que aún hoy sigue siendo objeto de estudio. La etnobotánica no solo rescata saberes ancestrales, sin que también promueve el respeto por el patrimonio cultural y biológico de los pueblos.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Pre-Columbian cultures developed complex systems of classification and use of plants that still survive today. For example, the Muiscas used fique to make rope and fabrics, coca for sacred rituals and corn as a central food in their diet. 
In the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, the Kogui and Arhuacos maintain a spiritual vision of the plant world, considering plants as “sisters” that speak, feel and teach. Plants were used not only for their physical properties, but also for their spiritual symbolism: a plant could protect against negative energies, attract good luck or help in making important decisions.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Indigenous communities have a unique worldview that integrates the natural with the spiritual. Each plant has a spirit and a purpose. For example, Yagé (Ayahuasca) is considered by Amazonian peoples as a master plant that teaches and guides through visions. The knowledge of what plant to use, how to prepare it and when to collect it is transmitted through rituals, chants and traditional practices.
In Colombia, more than 6,000 plant species have been documented for traditional use, many of which have not yet been studied by science. This ancestral knowledge is at risk due to the loss of indigenous languages and the westernization of new generations.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Many plants used today in modern medicine were discovered thanks to traditional knowledge. Example:


- Borrachero (Brugmansia): has been used by shamans to induce altered states of consciousness, but also has risks due to its toxicity.
- Aloe Vera: known for its healing and anti-inflammatory properties.
- Chamomile: used for digestive problems and to relieve anxiety.
- Cat's Claw: used in the Amazon, it has shown anti-inflammatory properties that are now being studied in laboratories.
- Quinine: extracted from the bark of the cinchona tree, it is an effective antimalarial.

A common myth is that “if it is natural, it does no harm”, but many plants can be dangerous if not prepared correctly. Today's science is working with communities to validate this knowledge and ensure its safe use.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Colombia is the second most biodiverse country in the world, and much of its flora is found in indigenous and peasant territories. By conserving these territories, the traditional knowledge associated with their plants is also protected. Ethnobotany makes it possible to document this knowledge before it disappears, especially in communities where elders are the sole bearers of knowledge. 
Organizations and universities work with communities to create ethnobotanical gardens, seed banks and environmental education programs. For example, the Ethnobotanical Garden of the SINCHI Institute in Leticia, Amazonas, where more than 200 species used by indigenous peoples are preserved.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Indigenous spirituality is deeply connected to plants. In many cultures, they are considered “spirit beings” that aid in healing and connection with the divine. Coca, sweet yucca and yagé are considered sacred plants in many Colombian communities, used in rituals of initiation, healing or contact with ancestors.
In Kogui rituals, for example, coca leaves are chewed during the “mambeada”, while talking about the harmony of the world. Respect for these plants also involves rituals of planting, care and harvesting with spiritual intention. These practices are being recognized in academic and legal spaces as part of Colombia's intangible cultural heritage.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
In many Colombian communities, knowledge about plants is possessed by elders known as sabedores, curanderos or shamans. These spiritual guides learn from childhood to observe, collect and prepare plants, guided by their dreams, visions and the direct teaching of their elders. In the Uitoto culture, for example, it is considered that a plant must be “requested” from the forest, showing respect and gratitude by collecting it.
The figure of the healer has been stigmatized by modern society, but today there is a movement to revalue this knowledge as a living heritage. The preservation of this knowledge depends on intercultural dialogue and the legal and social recognition of the rights of native peoples.

question.question: Who is considered the ‚ÄúFather of Ethnobotany?

pill.title: CONCLUSIONS
pill.content:
Ethnobotany reminds us that knowledge about plants is not only scientific, but also cultural and spiritual. Through the study of plants and their traditional uses, we better understand the history, medicine and identity of peoples. Preserving this ancestral knowledge is vital to face current challenges such as biodiversity loss and the search for sustainable solutions.
Valuing indigenous wisdom and promoting dialogue between science and tradition opens up new possibilities for a future that is more conscious and respectful of nature.

posts.title: Useful and Common Plants
posts.description: Plants have been fundamental allies in everyday life. From medicinal herbs to essential ingredients in the kitchen, many species provide us with incredible benefits. Discover here some of the most commonly used plants and their multiple uses in health, food and wellness. üå±‚ú®

pill.title: INTRODUCTION
pill.content: Welcome, did you know that the plains foothills are an important area for being the transition between the mountain ecosystems and the savannah, and this condition has endowed it with a great diversity of species, landscapes and social dynamics.

Among the main causes of biodiversity loss are fragmentation (loss of continuity of an ecosystem), degradation (loss of natural environmental conditions) and loss of natural connectivity caused by the expansion of the agricultural frontier, changes in land use, deforestation and overexploitation of natural resources. Given this scenario, maintaining ecosystems and the natural connectivity between them becomes an essential task for the conservation of biodiversity and the services it provides.


Among the strategies that Corporinoquia has considered for the conservation of bio-diversity is the creation of protected areas, which must be complemented with specific actions that guarantee the functionality of the landscapes (matrix) in which they are inserted, so that they maintain connectivity and the flow of energy and services, one of these actions are the biological corridors.

pill.title: WHAT IS BIODIVERSITY?
pill.content:
The Convention on Biological Diversity (the international instrument for "the conservation of biological diversity, the sustainable use of its components and the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of the utilization of genetic resources", which has been ratified by 196 countries), the term biodiversity or biological diversity refers to the variety of living organisms of any kind. This variety can be expressed in terms of different species, variability within a single species, or the existence of different ecosystems. An ecosystem is the basic functional unit of nature. It comprises living organisms, the non-living environment, and their interrelationships.


Colombia has more than 54,000 species registered in the Global Biodiversity Information Infrastructure (GBIF) (2016), sharing with Brazil the first place in the world in terms of biodiversity and is identified by the United Nations Environment Program as one of the 17 mega-diverse countries that host 70% of the world's biodiversity in only 10% of the territory.

pill.title: IMPORTANT DATA ON BIODIVERSITY IN COLOMBIA
pill.content:
Currently, in terms of biodiversity, Colombia is:

  • The first country in bird and orchid diversity.
  • The second country in plant, amphibian, river fish and butterfly diversity.
  • The third country in reptile and palm diversity.
  • The fourth country in mammal diversity.

Colombia is also characterized by the importance of natural forests, which cover 53% of the national continental territory and concentrate more than half of the terrestrial animal and plant species.

pill.title: WHAT ARE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES?
pill.content: Ecosystem services have been defined as the benefits that humans obtain from ecosystems, whether economic or cultural. Biodiversity supports a great variety of them that can be:

• Supporting services, e.g. soil formation, nutrient cycling, primary production.
  • Provisioning services, e.g., food, drinking water, firewood, fiber, biological chemicals, genetic resources. The most emblematic case in Colombia is probably that of the páramos, ecosystems that represent less than 2% of the Colombian territory but provide water to 70% of the population.
  • Regulatory services, e.g. climate regulation, disease regulation, water regulation, water purification, pollination.
  • Cultural services, e.g., spiritual and religious, recreation and ecotourism, aesthetics, inspiration, education, location, cultural heritage.

All these benefits to society are made possible by biodiversity and its ecosystems, and the well-being of present and future generations on the planet depends on them.

pill.title: P√ÅRAMO ECOSYSTEM
pill.content:
The páramo is considered a humid tropical ecosystem normally located above the upper forest limit (Castañeda, 2016; Hofstede et al., 2014), dominated by herbaceous and shrub vegetation (Crespo et al., 2009) and with cold bioclimatic landscapes (above 3,200 m a.s.l. and its highest peak is at 5,493 masl) (Castañeda, 2016) (Castañeda, 2016). The páramo is not only a tropical high mountain ecosystem, but also a production and work space with great history, culture and politics (Hofstede et al., 2014; Serrano & Galárraga, 2015).


The páramos are considered strategic ecosystems especially for their role in the regulation of the hydrological cycle that sustains the supply of water resources for human consumption and development of economic activities of more than 70% of the Colombian population, these territories are also characterized by their high biotic and sociocultural richness.

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA
pill.content:
Regarding the biodiversity of the páramos, it is better defined as unique rather than rich, as it has a high level of endemism and specialization, both at the genetic and landscape levels, promoted by its isolated and fragmented occurrence (Castro, 2011).


In this region there is a vegetation of grasses, shrubs, herbs, tundra and peat. There are low trees with permanent leaves, lichens, mosses and grasses.


Among the main species of flora of the páramo are the following:

 

  • The frailejón (Espeletia hartwegiana).
  • Páramo moss (Sphagnum sp).
  • The páramo star (Paepalanthus alpinus).
  • The seven red leather (Tibouchina grossa).
  • The flowers of Thristerix sp.
  • The blue phytophthora (Centaurea sp).
  • The alstroemerias.
  • Moor arnica (Senecio formosus).
  • Purple tobacco (Nicotiana sp).
  • Bromeliads (Puya sp).
  • The chuscales (Chusquea scandens)
  • The macolla (Calamagrostis effusa)
  • Chocho (Lupinus tolimensis)
  • Sanalotododo (Baccharis tericuneata)

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FAUNA
pill.content:
Some of the most representative animals of the moorlands are:

 

  • Copetón (Zonotrichia capensis)
  • Andean Condor (Vultur gryphus)
  • Páramo Barbudito (Oxypogon guerinii)
  • Hummingbirds (Eriocnemis vestita, Lesbia victoriae, Pterophanes cyanopterus, Coeligena heliantea)
  • Paramuna Pipit (Anthus bogotensis)
  • Tanager (Diglossa lafresnayii, Anisognathus igniventris)
  • Collared Magpie (Cyanolyca armillata)
  • Paramund Sparrow (Geospizopsis unicolor)
  • Paramund Duck (Anas andium)
  • Tinajo (Cuniculus taczanowskii)
  • Spectacled bear (Tremarctos ornatus)
  • Frogs (Atelopus carrikeri, Pristimantis sp, Dendropsophus luddeckei )
  • Butterflies (Vanessa sp, Greta sp, Altinote sp, Dione sp, Steremnia sp, Pedaliodes sp)
  • Tigrillos (Leopardus sp)
  • Foxes Lycalopex culpaeus
  • Tapir (Tapirus pinchaque)

pill.title: MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES
pill.content:
The páramos possess great biodiversity and provide several ecosystem services of great importance at the biological, hydrological, social, cultural and economic levels (Ayala et al., 2014); for example, water regulation, carbon sequestration, soil protection, biodiversity conservation, among others (Calderón et al., 2013; Farley et al., 2011).

Category * Concept Perceived elements
Provisioning Ecosystem Services (EES) Material goods that sustain Water, firewood, straw, food, medicinal plants.
Regulating ecosystem services (SER) Benefits influencing quality of life Clean air, water regulation and sanitation.
Cultural ecosystem services (CES) Direct and indirect contact with the ecosystem. Scenic beauty, beautiful fauna and flora, tranquility, site identity, heritage.
Supporting ecosystem services (SES) Functions that favor the development of ecological and biological processes. Soil formation, nutrient recycling, photosynthesis.

pill.title: HIGH ANDEAN FOREST ECOSYSTEM
pill.content: The Andean Forests are mountain ecosystems, with a wide range of elevation; they are framed between 2,000 m.a.s.l. and 3,500 m.a.s.l., they are located in the Andes mountain range, in cold and very cold lands, between 12 and 17.5 ° C.

gallery.title: Es hora de los bosques andinos

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA
pill.content:
The forest canopy is formed by the canopy of myrtles (Luma apiculata), amarraboyos (Meriania nobilis), sarros ferns (Cyathea microdonta), chagualos (Clusia sp), sietecueros (Andesanthus lepidotus) and several species of palms (macana (Wettinia kalbreyeri), among others). Some plants grow over others and sometimes strangle them, as do the matapalos and other species. Some emergent trees stand out from the canopy, such as oaks (Quercus humboldtii), laurels (Laurus nobilis), encenillos (Weinmannia tomentosa), chaquiros (Retrophyllum rospigliosii), bear's paw (Oreopanax incisus) and wax palms.


And a variety of epiphytes, mosses (Sphagnum spp), lichens, orchids, bromeliads, araceae, ferns (Selaginellas).

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FAUNA
pill.content:
In the high Andean forest live, among others, Andean bears - also known as spectacled bears (Tremarctos ornatus) -, wolf guaguas (Cuniculus paca), cusumbos (Nasuella olivacea), white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus), bush dogs and foxes (Lycalopex culpaeus). Several species of butterflies, such as the glass butterfly (Greta sp), the mirror butterfly (Agraulis sp.), as well as moths, bees, wasps, beetles, and stick insects, fly gently and slowly along the edges of the forest and on the banks of the streams.


Several arachnids also live there, among them some species of spiders, tarantulas and scorpions; some snakes, most of them hunters, such as the "tierreras" or "bobas" (Atractus crassicaudatus), the black hunter, the "juetiadora" or "lomo de machete" (Chironius flavopictus) and the cold ground viper (Atractus crassicaudatus), "colgadora" or "granadilla" (Spilotes pullatus); There are also several species of frogs, such as the so-called glass frogs (Centrolenidae sp), which sing at dusk, and many species of birds and birds, such as the Copetón (Zonotrichia capensis), Andean Condor (Vultur gryphus), Barbudito de Páramo (Oxypogon guerinii), Hummingbirds (Eriocnemis vestita, Lesbia victoriae, Pterophanes cyanopterus, Coeligena heliantea), Blackbirds (Mimus gilvus, Turdus fuscater), Emerald toucan (Aulacorhynchus prasinus), Owls (Ciccaba albitarsis, Megascops choliba), Mountain guan (Penelope sp).

pill.title: MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES
pill.content:
The Andean forest is one of the main providers of ecosystem services among the most representative are:


Maintaining the habitat of animals and plants: the biodiversity of the forest is very high and presents a large number of species that in some cases are endemic. Intrinsically, the forest's biodiversity reflects several services it provides, such as shelter for species, including endemic species, habitat maintenance and regeneration, provision of medicinal plants (Bubb, May, Miles, & Sayer, 2004), ornamental plants, raw material for handicrafts, pollination or timber uses (Armenteras, Cadena, & Moreno, 2007).


Water supply: plays an important role in the hydrological cycle since it acts as a regulating agent maintaining water sources (Armenteras, Cadena, & Moreno, 2007), it also regulates river flows helping to control and maintain water flows during dry times (Tobón, 2009).


Water from forests is used for agricultural production (irrigation water), livestock, industry, energy generation, human consumption, recreation, etc. (Armenteras, Cadena, & Moreno, 2007).


Carbon sequestration: High Andean forests are also of utmost importance in the provision of services such as carbon sequestration and fixation (Bubb, May, Miles, & Sayer, 2004) and the regulation and participation in the natural cycles of nutrients such as nitrogen and phosphorus (Caballero-Rueda, Rodríguez, & Martín, 1997).

pill.title: PIEDMONT ECOSYSTEM
pill.content: The piedmont of the plains is variously defined by several authors, some of whom state that it is a region that lies between 50 and 1100 meters above sea level in the eastern part of the eastern cordillera of the Andean mountain system (Becerra, 2009), while others indicate that it lies below 1000 meters above sea level in the same mountain range (Alexander Von Humboldt Institute, 2009). However, all of these define it as an area of great ecosystem diversity and of vital importance for the inhabitants of the region.

This ecosystem constitutes a biological corridor for transitory species between the Amazon, Orinoquia and the Andean mountain system, such as the Jaguar (Alexander Von Humboldt Institute, 2009). The main characteristic of the piedmont are the tall, dense and diverse forests, developed on the gently sloping plains to the east of the glacis (inclined plane of weak slope), which extend to the foot of the eastern margin of the Andes Mountains in their contact with the Amazonian plains.

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA
pill.content:
Some of the most representative species of this ecosystem are:

 

  • Caruto - Genipa americana
  • Cress Cumin - Aniba perutilis
  • Plum tree - Spondias mombin
  • Caimarón - Pourouma cecropiifolia Mart
  • Cacay - Caryodendron orinocense
  • Avichure - Couma macrocarpa Barb
  • Frijolillo - Abarema jupunba
  • Gualanday - Jacaranda copaia
  • Balso blanco - Heliocarpus popayanensis
  • Corocito - Aiphanes aculeata
  • Conacaste - Enterolobium schomburgkii
  • Orchid - Peristeria violacea
  • Naumo - Pseudosamanea guachapele
  • Saman - Samanea saman

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FAUNA
pill.content:
Some of the most representative species of this ecosystem are:

 

  • Hummingbird - Chlorostilbon poortmanni
  • Jacamará - Brachygalba goeringi
  • Juan bobo - Hypnelus ruficollis Espinero - Phacellodomus rufifrons
  • Flycatcher - Phelpsia inornata
  • Yellow-cheeked bogeyman - Vireolanius eximius
  • Jaguar - Panthera onca
  • Four nosed - Bothrops atrox
  • Coporo - Prochilodus mariae
  • Jumper - Salminus hilarii
  • Crested toad - Rhinella margaritifera
  • Frog - Pristimantis frater
  • Frog - Pristimantis carranguerorum
  • Green Macaw - Ara militaris
  • Eagle - Buteogallus solitarius
  • Paujil - Pauxi pauxi
  • Pava - Penelope purpurascens
  • Parakeet - Pyrilia pyrilia
  • Toucan - Ramphastos ambiguus
  • Toucan - Ramphastos tucanus
  • Araguato - Alouatta seniculus
  • Lapa - Cuniculus paca
  • Churuco - Lagothrix lugens
  • Tigrillo - Leopardus tigrinus
  • Otter - Lontra longicaudis
  • White-tailed deer - Odocoileus virginianus
  • Puma - Puma concolor
  • Red-tailed squirrel - Sciurus granatensis

pill.title: MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES
pill.content:
The piedmont ecosystem, thanks to its great biodiversity, contributes significantly to the following ecosystem services:


- Support Services: Support services are those that have the function of maintenance on the ecosystem itself, they are services necessary for the production of other ecosystem services (Valdez, 2011). In this sense, the ecosystem support services provided by the Piedemonte are divided into 5 functions, which are:

 

  • Maintaining biodiversity
  • Soil formation
  • Genetic material
  • Pollination
  • Nutrient supply.


- Regulatory Services: Regulating services are those obtained from the regulation of the ecosystem itself (Valdez, 2011), for example, carbon storage. In this sense, the ecosystem support services provided by the piedmont are divided into 5 main functions:

 

  • Water resource
  • Climate regulation
  • Climate change regulation and mitigation
  • Gas regulation
  • Moisture retention
  • Waste treatment and regulation.


- Provisioning Services: Provisioning services are those that are obtained directly from the ecosystem such as timber, water resources, food, raw materials, energy and minerals, housing, and provision of shade and shelter.


- Cultural Services: Cultural services are those that provide non-material benefits obtained from the ecosystem such as an educational, recreational or tourism service (Valdez, 2011), such as:

 

  • Recreation and tourism
  • Cultural information
  • Spirituality
  • Shelter
  • Education
  • Ornamental elements

pill.title: SAVANNA ECOSYSTEM
pill.content:
The main characteristic of the Colombian savannah is that for eight months of the year it is flooded, and the other four months are extremely dry and have an intertropical climate.


The region located to the west of the Meta River, known as the Casanare and Arauca savannas, is probably the largest extension of land in the north of the South American continent, which is below 200 m of altitude. These plains, subject to flooding for approximately seven to eight months of the year, have a rainy period between March and November and a short summer from December to February; to the east, its boundary is defined by a geological fault that runs southwest-northeast. The Meta River follows the course of this fault and undermines the walls of the eastern block - the altillanura - which is almost 40 to 50 m higher.


The region that preserves this ecosystem is bordered to the north and east by the Republic of Venezuela, to the south by Colombia's Amazon region and to the west by the Eastern Cordillera (Andes mountain range) and includes the departments of Arauca, Casanare, Meta, Vichada and Norte del Guaviare (IGAC, 2008).

The topography is flat and concave, with particularly low areas that correspond to lowlands and marshes that flood during the rainy season (floodable savannas).


Some representative economic activities are cattle ranching, oil exploitation and rice cultivation, as well as the recently introduced oil palm cultivation.

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA
pill.content:
Some of the most representative species of this ecosystem are:

 

  • Hobo - Spondias mombin
  • Chirimiyo - Annona montana
  • Manirita - Annona jahnii
  • Malagueto - Xylopia aromatica
  • Cubarro - Bactris major
  • Bototo - Cochlospermum vitifolium
  • Moriche - Mauritia flexuosa
  • Strawberry tree - Garcinia madruno
  • Evergreen - Gomphrena globosa
  • Yarumo - Cecropia engleriana
  • Spider creeper - Monstera adansonii
  • Tote - Rhynchospora albescens
  • Savannah star - Rhynchospora barbata
  • Tote - Rhynchospora nervosa
  • Oil - Copaifera pubiflora
  • Royal palm - Attalea butyracea
  • Catfish thorn - Hydrolea spinosa
  • Boron - Limnocharis flava
  • Pate vaca - Bauhinia aculeata
  • Guamo - Inga sp.

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FAUNA
pill.content:
Some of the most representative species of this ecosystem are:

 

  • Chiguiro - Hydrochoerushydrochaeris
  • Deer - Odocoileus virginianus
  • Palm bear - Myrmecophaga tridactyla
  • Honey bear - Tamandua tetradactyla
  • Morrocoy - Chelonoidis carbonaria
  • Araguato - Alouatta seniculus
  • Guiri duck - Dendrocygna viduata
  • Wild rat - Proechimys oconnelli
  • Stone Curlew - Vanellus chilensis
  • Warbler - Athene cunicularia
  • Chenchena - Opisthocomus hoazín
  • Chickadee - Jabiru mycteria
  • Arrendajo - Cacicus cela
  • Corocora - Eudocimus ruber
  • Grey heron - Platalea ajaja
  • Caracara - Daptrius chimachima
  • Bonparado - Nyctibius griseus
  • Flycatcher - Phelpsia inornata
  • Aruco - Anhima cornuta
  • Chácharo - Pecari tajacu
  • Picure - Dasyprocta fuliginosa
  • Cachicamo - Dasypus novemcinctus
  • Curito - Hoplosternum littorale
  • Caiman - Crocodilus intermedius
  • Charapa - Podocnemis expansa
  • Terecay - Podocnemis unifilis
  • Puma - Puma concolor
  • Fox - Cerdocyon thous
  • Hunter - Chironius carinatus
  • Trail Ranger - Liophis lineatus

pill.title: MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES
pill.content:
Savannas provide many environmental services, for example, the following:


Provisioning services: food production such as fish, seafood, livestock, soils for crops and water sources for human consumption.


Regulating and supporting services: water regulation in savannas, air quality with carbon sequestration, regulation of nutrient cycling, as well as surface water cycling, erosion control, productivity and climate change mitigation.


Support services: Savannas conserve and maintain biodiversity by providing shelter for many species of fauna, flora and fungi that contribute to the supply of nutrients and soil formation, thus contributing to the safeguarding of genetic material and promoting pollination.


Cultural services: recreation, education, and tourism, with activities such as sport fishing, bird watching, and ecological hikes. Resources for natural medicines and ancestral knowledge.

pill.title: CONSERVATION PLANS
pill.content:
Action plans for the conservation of species and ecosystems are indispensable tools in biodiversity conservation. To formulate a conservation action plan/program, conservation priorities are defined, for example: to make decisions about the most threatened species that require preferential attention and to define clear goals for their conservation. Based on a detailed analysis of the conservation problem, a conservation action plan/program also provides guidelines on actions that are critical to achieving conservation goals and monitoring progress toward goals to adjust practices accordingly.


Next, we will show you some of the conservation plans that CORPORINOQUIA executes for the protection of fauna and flora species:

 

  • Action Plan for the protection of the Andean Bear (Tremarctos Ornatus):

pill.title: Structural biological corridor for the lowland tapir (Tapirus terrestres):

pill.content: Conservation and management plan for white-tailed deer (odocoileus virginianus) in the jurisdiction of corporinoquia, specifically in the municipalities of paz de ariporo, hato corozal, mani and tauramena in the department of Casanare.
Conservation plan for the anteater anteater (myrmecophaga tridactyla) and the honey anteater (tamandua tetradactyla) for the departments of arauca, casanare and vichada.
"Conservation and management plan for mauritia flexuosa (moriche or cananguche) in the departments of casanare, arauca and vichada jurisdiction of corporinoquia".

FOR YOUR INFORMATION!!!....


It should be noted that CORPORINOQUIA, in addition to these, carries out more conservation plans in other species of Fauna and Flora of great importance within the area of its jurisdiction, for more information about these plans you can request them directly to the Corporation or by the means of commination provided by the same Corporation.

question.question: Does the term biodiversity or biological diversity refer to the variety of living organisms of any kind, and can it also be expressed in terms of different species?

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know that...


Colombia has more than 54,000 species registered in the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF), sharing with Brazil the first place in the world in terms of biodiversity and is identified by the United Nations Environment Program as one of the 17 megadiverse countries that host 70% of the world's biodiversity in only 10% of the territory.

posts.title: Conservation, Awareness
posts.description: The wisdom of ancient cultures has taught us the value of plants and their importance in our lives. Today, more than ever, it is essential to protect this knowledge and the ecosystems that sustain it. Through the conservation and rescue of endangered species, we can ensure that future generations will continue to benefit from the natural and cultural wealth that surrounds us. üåé‚ú®

gallery.title: Hiking through our paramos (P√°ramo de las Burras - Cundinamarca)

pill.title: CONTENTS
pill.content:
1. Clean water and living watersheds
    1.1. The water basin as a system
        1.1.1. Parts of a water basin
        1.1.2. Ecosystem services in a watershed
    1.2. Colombia's watersheds
        1.2.1. What is a macro watershed?
        1.2.2. How many macro-watersheds are there in the country?
    1.3. Strategic macro-basin plans
        1.3.1. Importance of the strategic plans of Macrobasins
    1.4. Water resource management - Corporinoquia
        1.4.1. Corporinoquia's POMCAS
        1.4.2. Water Resource Management Plan

pill.title: Welcome
pill.content:
Hello I am Regulo Palma!


The Moriche grandfather of the Corporinoquia family and I want to invite you to immerse yourself in the water resources of the Orinoquia, so we can travel together, the Orinoco river basin and you can learn about the importance, care and conservation of water.


Did you know that almost 5 departments are part of the corporation's jurisdiction? That's right, Arauca, Casanare and Vichada are part of it and what unites us with the other two departments is water, because some of the most important tributaries of the region are born in ten municipalities of Cundinamarca and five of Boyacá.


I will invite you to know the most important water sources of our territory!

pill.title: THE RIVER BASIN AS A SYSTEM
pill.content: A watershed is defined as the area of surface or groundwater that flows into a hydrographic network with one or more natural watercourses; these can be of continuous or intermittent flow, which converge in a larger course, which in turn can flow either into a main river, a natural water reservoir, a swamp or directly into the sea (Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development, 2014).

However, the watershed is a complex system composed of physical elements such as geological structure, water resources, climate and soils; biological elements such as flora, fauna and ecosystems; as well as anthropogenic, cultural, socioeconomic and institutional elements, which are deeply interrelated and, as a whole, confer particular characteristics (Tapia, 1994).


It should be pointed out that watersheds are like our circulatory system, in which veins and arteries function as networks to transport blood from the tissues to the lungs. A watershed may be made up of several sub-watersheds, which in turn are made up of micro-watersheds.

pill.title: PARTS OF A RIVER BASIN
pill.content:
High basin: it is located in the upper part of the mountains and is where the river originates. Normally in this area there is a steeper slope and the small threads of water that flow move at high speed. The water is colder and has a low concentration of nutrients. There we find a high diversity of organisms, mostly of small size. In this zone many species feed on the leaves that fall into the water from the trees along the river.


Middle basin: the slope is reduced and the volume of water in the river, the temperature and the concentration of nutrients in the water increase. This zone is normally the site of most agricultural and livestock activities.


Low basin: located at low altitudes and flat areas, the water velocity is reduced, nutrient concentrations increase and the water is more turbid. This zone is normally subject to the greatest fishing activity. Colombia is also characterized by the importance of natural forests, which cover 53% of the national continental territory and account for more than half of the country's terrestrial animal and plant species.

pill.title: ECOSYSTEM SERVICES IN A WATERSHED
pill.content:
Water supply for domestic, agricultural and industrial consumption is one of the main ecosystem services provided by rivers, streams and creeks that are part of a watershed.


Agriculture and food security depend to a large extent on surface water and sediments transported through the watersheds, and they also provide hydroelectric power.


A watershed in a good state of conservation regulates surface runoff, prevents and reduces flooding and the risk of landslides, provides natural resources for the development of productive activities, and allows recreation and the enjoyment of an attractive landscape.


It should be noted that watersheds are a space for the productive, social, and cultural development of society and a habitat for fauna and flora.

pill.title: RIVER BASINS OF COLOMBIA
pill.content:
What is a macro watershed?


According to the IDEAM (IDEAM, 2013) hydrographic areas or macrobasins correspond to hydrographic regions or watersheds. These areas are large regions that group basins and rivers that flow into the same sea.


How many macro basins are there in the country?


Colombia has a dense hydrographic network of more than 700,000 micro-basins, which are physically defined in five large hydrographic regions (Minagriculture and FAO 2014). The first four (4) that strictly comply with the definition of watershed, these are: i) Orinoco, ii) Amazon, iii) Atlantic (Caribbean) and iv) Pacific.


The fifth hydrographic area was defined based on its importance in the socioeconomic context of the country, this is v) Magdalena-Cauca.

gallery.title: Ubicaci√≥n y extensi√≥n de las Macrocuencas

pill.content:
Corporinoquia's jurisdiction is located in the Orinoco Hydrographic Area, which in turn is divided into 59 Hydrographic Subzones established to facilitate the management and administration of water resources.

The following is a visualization of its jurisdiction:

pill.title: MACROBASIN STRATEGIC PLANS
pill.content:
The EMPs are a "long-term environmental planning instrument that, with a national vision, constitutes the framework for the formulation, adjustment and/or execution of the different instruments of policy, planning, planning, management, and follow-up existing in each one of them".


For the preparation of these plans, the following phases are developed:

 

  • Baseline: comprises the analysis of available technical, scientific, economic, social and environmental information and identification of actors involved in the planning of the natural resources of the Macrobasin, as well as the main conflicts and natural and unintentional anthropic conflicts and risks related to natural resources.
  • Diagnosis: Involves the identification and evaluation of factors and variables that affect the development of the macrobasin, associated with changes in the state of water resources and other natural resources.
  • Strategic analysis: Addresses the process of agreeing on the desired model for the respective macro-basin, based on which the guidelines and directives for the integrated management of water and other natural resources are defined.
  • Agreements and strategic actions: includes the definition of agreements, actions and investments that may be implemented by each of the key stakeholders.

pill.title: IMPORTANCE OF STRATEGIC PLANS FOR MACROBASINS
pill.content:
The Strategic Plan of the respective Macrobasin constitutes the framework for:

 

  • The formulation of the new Watershed Management and Management Plans (POMCAS) within the Macrobasin, as well as for the adjustment of those that have already been formulated.
  • The formulation of the Management Plans for the Marine-Coastal and Oceanic Environmental Units, as well as for the adjustment of those already formulated.
  • The formulation of the Environmental Management Plans for micro-basins and aquifers, as well as for the adjustment of those that have already been formulated.
  • The structuring of the national water resource monitoring network.
  • The formulation of regional and/or local sectoral public policies.
  • The formulation of the new four-year action plans of the regional environmental authorities, in accordance with the obligations stipulated in Decree 1200 of 2004 and other regulatory norms.
  • Establish criteria and guidelines for the hydrological management of the main rivers of the macrobasin by the environmental authorities, in terms of quantity and quality, as well as water uses at the subarea level.
  • Establish strategies and actions to improve the governance of water resources and other natural resources in the macrobasin.


In the following section, the POMCAS will be discussed in more detail.

pill.title: CORPORINOQUIA FARMS
pill.content:
The POMCA is the planning instrument through which the coordinated use of soil, water, flora and fauna and the management of the basin is planned.


The country has 396 river basins subzones and subsequent level (394 continental and San Andres and Providencia) that are subject to planning and management, in accordance with the provisions of the Single Regulatory Decree of the Environment Sector Decree 1076 of 2015, which compiles among others Decree 1640 of 2012.


Corporinoquia in its jurisdiction has 21 regulated POMCAS, of which 15 are in force and have been updated through different contractual processes.

The following map shows the location of the 21 POMCAS:

To learn more about Corporinoquia's current POMCAS follow the links below:

The environmental zoning of the POMCAs is presented below:

pill.title: WATER RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN
pill.content:
Water resource management is a planning instrument that affects the administration of inland surface water resources and allows the competent environmental authority to establish the destination and use of inland surface water bodies, establish standards, conditions and a monitoring program to achieve and maintain the potential uses of water, as well as to conserve biological cycles and the normal development of species, over a minimum ten-year horizon.


The following is Corporinoquia's water resource management plan for 9 water sources:

gallery.title: Plan de ordenamiento del recurso h√≠drico

pill.content:
Here we end the wonderful tour of the ORINOCO BASIN, I hope you have learned a lot, please take a message home about conservation and care of water in our territory, finally, do not forget!


1. Avoid throwing garbage in the water sources.
2. Do not contaminate rivers with chemical waste, soaps and/or detergents.
3. Do not cut down trees.
4. Never throw oil or fuels down the siphons of our houses.
5. Remember, excessive consumption of plastics and poor disposal is a growing threat, clogging the flow of rivers and endangering ecosystems.
6. Please, when you go for a family outing to the river, do not leave garbage, ashes or plastics, these contaminate our water sources and with it you end the life of thousands of organisms that live under the water.


TOGETHER we can take care of the ORINOQUIA'S WATER RESOURCES.
CORPORINOQUIA - A Pact for Our Land

Watersheds are like our circulatory system, in which veins and arteries function as networks to transport blood from the tissues to the lungs. A watershed can be made up of several sub-watersheds, which in turn are made up of micro-watersheds.

posts.title: The alligator toom
posts.description: It tells the story of the caiman toom, an old and gigantic specimen that protects its eggs day and night from the terrible human claws, so that they can know the wonderful life that the tributary of the Orinoco offers them.

posts.title: Mama capybara and the drought of the plains
posts.description: During the year, mother capybara and her children enjoy their life in the vicinity of the Pauto river, but the long arm of pollution and destruction has reached their home, now they must flee and find a new home for their children, lives the story of Capybara mom, our heroine.

pill.title: Mama capybara and the drought of the plains

posts.title: Lola A Mother's Drama
posts.description: Lola, the otter and her children are threatened when a group of animal traffickers arrives on the river bank, who, upon realizing the presence of the otters, see the possibility of selling them to earn money.

posts.title: Super Hero Teddy Anteater
posts.description: "Samy" is a very outgoing anteater who lives happily with his mother but he wants to find new friends so he can have fun in the pond, but this fun is obstructed by the problems that his species and its habitat live due to the evil actions of man. and the monster "petroleum".

posts.title: What are we mom?
posts.description: Faced with the disturbing question of her children, the woolly chucha responds and argues about the identity of their species and the importance they are for the ecosystem.

posts.title: Forest Olympics
posts.description: The story takes place in the forest where all the tapirs once a year met to do their diving competitions and decide who was the best, the winner gave them various seeds to eat and plant and thus counteract the felling of trees.

posts.title: Branches of the trade
posts.description: Yaki is one of the few night monkeys whose family is still complete and reunited; despite the stalking scientists and the continuous fighting between legal and illegal armed groups.

posts.title: Man Stains
posts.description: Othello seems to be used to eating the animals of a nearby farm, the owner although annoying, limits himself to scare him away, but a hunter offers to get rid of the 'problem' at no cost, in the end due to the circumstances the farmer recognizes that it is not the fault of the animal, but of those who invade their environment.

posts.title: No Hunting like at Home
posts.description: Kata is a lonely limpet and with traumas of course abandonment, she was too young to understand the circumstances in which her parents died at the hands of hunters, escaping from one of them she finds her partner and with whom they will persevere so as not to let her your species is eradicated.

posts.title: Slow Leakage, Fast Conclusion
posts.description: We have Roko on the scene, a male long-nosed turtle whose hobby is ... letting time go by. In one of his routines he is found by a group of indigenous people who capture him and reunite with others of the same species. One of them warns him about his destiny: to be merchandise or food.

posts.title: Prejudicial Protection
posts.description: Totema is a cunning, persistent and brave turtle, but that will not reach him until he realizes that his fight has an end.

posts.title: Grandma Goose
posts.description: "Every day an old goose sees how her environment changes, and the poor little geese have to adapt to the changes that damage their ecosystem and their way of life, read the stories of Leonor the older goose."

posts.title: Free-flown
posts.description: Xalma is caged in a truck about to be sold. From her confinement, she tells us her story without suspecting that she will have a positive outcome, although only for her.

posts.title: What Parrots Talk About
posts.description: It tells how an obese parrot got to this condition due to the irresponsible care of human beings. A contradictory way to conserve the species, as deforestation has led these creatures to reduce their numbers.

posts.title: In Other People's Skin
posts.description: Tasko is a pollero wolf, a lizard with a great appetite and a confident character. Initially, he is stressed at the thought that he was abandoned by his family, but he will discover thanks to an old friendship that his children did not leave voluntarily, but instead became articles of clothing and fashion accessories for unconcerned people.

posts.title: Teacher Pepperan
posts.description: "In each school day the teacher Pepperan teleported his students to times ago with his great and funny stories"

posts.title: Road of Roses Glorious Birds
posts.description: It is not enough for this striking specimen called Rozz to stand out, however, of its striking plumage and advantage to find food thanks to its spoon / spatula-shaped beak. but the wild life is raw and he must take it on with his characteristic good attitude.

posts.title: Stolen Thief and his Finished World
posts.description: The soldier garzon is a huge bird whose reputation as a predator is well known among those who have been the victims of its attacks. Iguaro will now discover that while he was stealing prey, he and all the birds were stealing their trees.

pill.title: Stolen Thief and his Finished World

posts.title: Until It's Over
posts.description: A group of deer that feed are ambushed by hunters who set fire to the area to confuse them, in the flight the youngest fall into the hands of men, which forces Azel to return, the young men manage to flee, but Azel stays in his replacement.

posts.title: Red Hot Celebration
posts.description: Ibis is an ordinary corocora, but it knows well what is good for it. When he realizes the evil that humans cause, he decides to simply leave, forming part of the migration statistics that report the red ibis as displaced from its habitat.

posts.title: Before and After, Here There Was a Fish
posts.description: There are no protagonists here, but there are antagonists depending on the point of view. The payara is feared for its ferocity and voracious appetite, but who the real monster is will soon be revealed. Man is killing this species due to overfishing.

pill.title: Before and After, Here There Was a Fish

posts.title: Fruit of the Exploration
posts.description: Some travelers (known as backpackers) get lost in the jungles of the Orinoco and decide to use nearby palms to guarantee survival. In an exaggerated way for narrative sake, they build all kinds of items and prepare some foods. Finally the reflection aims to be responsible and respectful with the use of this plant.

posts.title: Air Oranges
posts.description: There is nothing to worry about, the palo de cruz tree proliferates and its abundance benefits its environment. Polena will limit herself to discovering one of the most remarkable aspects of this species: its reproductive phase, at the end it will throw some pistils into the air inviting them to enjoy this flower.

posts.title: Wood in Ocaso
posts.description: A sad beginning, a knot that does not improve and an ending that gives hope. Logging kills the trees.

posts.title: It goes up like Palma...And there it stays...
posts.description: Here there will only be good omen, abundance and well-being. The corozo palm is a stable species and under good care.

pill.title: It goes up like Palma...And there it stays...

posts.title: Astucia? Pure Straw
posts.description: A plant whose flower pollen does not like? This seems to be the case, since it is a sporiferous plant. But is she bad enough to talk about her?
